did.unittitle: Dedication to his brother for From Death to Morning

scopecontent.p: [Includes ANS, Thomas Wolfe, Sante Fe, to Ester Owens, [ Tulsa, Oklahoma] regarding the dedication to Benjamin Harrison Wolfe, who died of influenza,]

did.unittitle: Thomas Wolfe, San Francisco, to Esther Owens, Sante Fe

scopecontent.p: [Declines her invitation to Sante Fesince he is due back in New York City; says he has a book coming out in October and that his holiday has come to an end; looks forward to seeing her again; sends love and friendship.]

did.unittitle: Thoms Wolfe, New York City, to Esther Owens, Tulsa, Oklahoma

scopecontent.p: [Declines invitation to Tulsa, saying that he and Maxwell Perkinshave decided to stay out of the lecture circuit, though he may lose money; thanks her for sending pair of rabbit's feet for luck; mentions being troubled and tormented since October with demands put on him; explains that he does need, and has little chance to win, the Pulitzer Prize, and that he had Perkins pull the book from consideration; expresses disappointment at not being able to see her soon.]

did.unittitle: Thomas Wolfe, New York City, to Esther Owens, Tulsa, Oklahoma

scopecontent.p: [Thanks her for Christmas present; sends season's greetings; looks forward to going home to North Carolinaand to seeing New Orleans; remembers a visit to New Orleansduring Mardi Gras when he was a child.]

did.unittitle: Thomas Wolfe, New York City, to Esther Owens, Tulsa, Oklahoma

scopecontent.p: [Talks about his "flu" or "grippe" after returning from the South; says he subsisted largely on her gifts of preserves and cheese; discusses his legal problems; maintain that the past 2 years have not made him bitter or cynical; finds comfort in her friendship.]

did.unittitle: Thomas Wolfe, New York City, to Esther Owens, Tulsa, Oklahoma

scopecontent.p: [Thanks her for preserves and remembers her previous practical gifts; hopes her examinations went well; relates his summer plans to work in a rented cabin near Asheville, North Carolinato cut, rewrite, and shape a gigantic manuscript; expects short stories to come out in Scribner's Magazineand The New Yorker; says he has sold stories to Redbookand Saturday Evening Postand is pleased about the profit.]
